body: @markusweimer  this is ready for review again
@nachocano Thanks, I will do another pass.
@nachocano  I'm done with my review. One question left. The code validates and tests just fine.

[Reef-pull-request-ubuntu #98](https://builds.apache.org/job/Reef-pull-request-ubuntu/98/) FAILURE
Looks like there's a problem with this pull request

@markusweimer  again, you are right. I just removed it. I've tested and seems to be working fine.
Thanks

[Reef-pull-request-windows2 #90](https://builds.apache.org/job/Reef-pull-request-windows2/90/) UNSTABLE
Looks like there's a problem with this pull request
@nachocano I'll test and merge if the tests pass.
I'm doing a review of this today.

@afchung I'm done with my pass. Several small items, but the code looks good overall, and the tests and validations pass.

Thinking about it from a simplification perspective, I wonder whether `REEFLauncher` and `LaunchHelper` couldn't be merged into one class, `REEFLauncher`. Its main would, outside of some logging, only load the config from `args[0]` and instantiate `REEFLauncher` and call `run` on it. 

The upside of that approach is that we could keep most of the `REEFLauncher` private, which should make it easier to refactor this in the future.

What do you think?
I am done this pass.
@jwang98052 @markusweimer , I have incorporated julia comments

@markusweimer shall we merge this PR and I will use REEF-472 to do the rename/refactor for the AllHandlers example?
I am looking at this PR.
Yes, I will test and merge this. It makes progress by itself and shouldn't have to wait for the next one.

[Reef-pull-request-ubuntu #106](https://builds.apache.org/job/Reef-pull-request-ubuntu/106/) SUCCESS
This pull request looks good

[Reef-pull-request-windows2 #98](https://builds.apache.org/job/Reef-pull-request-windows2/98/) UNSTABLE
Looks like there's a problem with this pull request

This implementation of a cache might be a bit too simple. For instance, the size of the caching dictionary would grow indefinitely. Also, how does one invalidate a cache entry? Also, this puts the decision of whether or not to use the cache to the application code, which usually can't make that discussion well. Have a look at `org.apache.reef.io.network.naming.NameLookupClient` on the java side for a more full-featured implementation.
There is also [System.Runtime.Caching](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.runtime.caching%28v=vs.110%29.aspx) with base implementations of caching libraries you might want to use.

ok.

On Thu, Jul 16, 2015 at 1:04 PM, Markus Weimer notifications@github.com
wrote:

> There is also System.Runtime.Caching
> https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.runtime.caching%28v=vs.110%29.aspx
> with base implementations of caching libraries you might want to use.
> 
> —

[Reef-pull-request-ubuntu #107](https://builds.apache.org/job/Reef-pull-request-ubuntu/107/) SUCCESS
This pull request looks good

@markus @jwang98052 , the logging function does not give duration in a variable but just prints it. I want to maintain running average of broadcast and reduce over iterations. Hence, will prefer going with StopWatch explicitly unless you guys strongly feel otherwise. Moreover, this is more like a user code than REEF code. Hence, we should be ok using StopWatch.
Fix pushed in.

[Reef-pull-request-windows2 #100](https://builds.apache.org/job/Reef-pull-request-windows2/100/) SUCCESS
This pull request looks good

This is a distributed cache. For a distributed cache, we must consider 
cache initialization
cache update
Auto refresh periodically
Failure over case
Out of sync case
etc. to avoid any potential issues and that would be much harder to debug at run time. 

The client lookup are only used in a few places. One is topology initialization. It is called once any way. The other place is Network service connection.Open(). We do cache the Connection but call Open() every time when sending a message. The open method look up from NameClient by id in case it is changed. If we cache it, we would better put the code in open() in Connection constructor but that might give us obsolete endpoints.

I see ... I am trying to look in to java side how they do it over
there....having some issues setting it up with eclipse...do you guys also
use eclipse.

Dhruv

On Thu, Jul 16, 2015 at 2:29 PM, Julia Wang notifications@github.com
wrote:

> This is a distributed cache. For a distributed cache, we must consider
> cache initialization
> cache update
> Auto refresh periodically
> Failure over case
> Out of sync case
> etc. to avoid any potential issues and that would be much harder to debug
> at run time.
> 
> The client lookup are only used in a few places. One is topology
> initialization. It is called once any way. The other place is Network
> service connection.Open(). We do cache the Connection but call Open() every
> time when sending a message. The open method look up from NameClient by id
> in case it is changed. If we cache it, we would better put the code in
> open() in Connection constructor but that might give us obsolete endpoints.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/apache/incubator-reef/pull/298#issuecomment-122104385
> .

So I looked at the java code. It is not handling the case where the cache
entry is invalid now. this has to be in some sense done by the user code.
For example, if the cached values does not work, mark the value as invalid
and force the update. AM I right?

Dhruv

On Thu, Jul 16, 2015 at 2:29 PM, Julia Wang notifications@github.com
wrote:

> This is a distributed cache. For a distributed cache, we must consider
> cache initialization
> cache update
> Auto refresh periodically
> Failure over case
> Out of sync case
> etc. to avoid any potential issues and that would be much harder to debug
> at run time.
> 
> The client lookup are only used in a few places. One is topology
> initialization. It is called once any way. The other place is Network
> service connection.Open(). We do cache the Connection but call Open() every
> time when sending a message. The open method look up from NameClient by id
> in case it is changed. If we cache it, we would better put the code in
> open() in Connection constructor but that might give us obsolete endpoints.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/apache/incubator-reef/pull/298#issuecomment-122104385
> .

I'm not convinced that making the serializer injectable has significant benefits compared to just keeping all methods static and never instantiating it. It looks like keeping methods static leads to cleaner and more understandable code. Let's keep it as is for now, and discuss whether we need a unified approach to serializers separately.

Using injection is helpful if we also use an interface, like we do with the `ConfigurationSerializer` interface and the `AvroConfigurationSerializer` implementation. Code can be written against the `ConfigurationSerializer` interface, and if we ever want to change the default implementation, it is very easy to do.

I cannot repro the issue in my env. I have made a few changes to reduce possible noises:
1. disabled RealtimeLogUpload in reef test. In fact, if you want that to work without errors in your log, you need to set environment variables for storage account
2. make assemblies used to generating class hierarchy injectable. Default is still get all the dll/exe from global folder. 
The change is pushed in.
BTW, delete package folder and lang/cs/bin folder before rebuild.

@markus @julia, I am confused over the logic in the following case: What happens if one re-registers or unregister itself in NameClient. Take the re-register case.
